Straight Drive.summary: A classical shot played along the ground straight back past the bowler.
Straight Drive.masters: Sachin Tendulkar, Virat Kohli, Kumar Sangakkara
Straight Drive.history: One of the oldest and purest cricket strokes, known as the symbol of textbook batting.
Straight Drive.improve: Keep head still, firm front knee, full extension of the bat.
alt_safe: Mid-off push for single
Mid-on push for quick rotation
Push past bowler along the ground
alt_aggressive: Loft over the bowler
Loft over long-off
Loft over long-on
final_feedback: Time your front-foot stride earlier.
Keep your head directly over the ball at impact.
Complete a full, relaxed follow-through.
Avoid falling toward the off side.
Meet the ball under your eyes, not beside your body.

Cover Drive.summary: Front-foot shot played through the covers with full face of the bat.
Cover Drive.masters: Babar Azam, Virat Kohli, Ian Bell
Cover Drive.history: The cover drive became iconic in Test cricket for elegance and timing.
Cover Drive.improve: Lean into the ball, open shoulder slightly, high elbow finish.
alt_safe: Punch along the ground through extra cover
Soft push to mid-off for a single
Check drive in front of cover fielder
alt_aggressive: Inside-out six over cover
Lofted extra-cover boundary
Loft over mid-off when the fielder is up
final_feedback: Stride toward the line of the ball, not across it.
Maintain a high elbow for a classical shape.
Let your hands flow through the line of the ball.
Stay balanced while leaning into the shot.
Contact the ball slightly in front of your pad.

On Drive.summary: Front-foot drive played towards mid-on with a straight bat.
On Drive.masters: Rahul Dravid, VVS Laxman, Kane Williamson
On Drive.history: Considered one of the toughest shots because it requires excellent timing and balance.
On Drive.improve: Transfer body weight smoothly and avoid falling over to the off side.
alt_safe: Clip gently to mid-on for one
Punch straight of mid-on along the ground
Glide off the pads toward deep midwicket for two
alt_aggressive: Loft over long-on
Power on-drive over mid-on
Whip over wide long-on for six
final_feedback: Keep your front knee strong and pointed down the pitch.
Avoid closing your stance too early.
Use your wrists to control the on-side angle.
Keep your head still and over the front leg.
Let your bat swing straight, not across your body.

Lofted Drive.summary: Aggressive aerial version of the drive clearing the infield.
Lofted Drive.fields: Long-off, long-on, straight down the ground.
Lofted Drive.masters: Rohit Sharma, AB de Villiers, David Warner
Lofted Drive.history: Popularized by ODI and T20 cricket to score boundaries and sixes.
Lofted Drive.improve: Stay tall, keep shape, full follow-through.
alt_safe: Controlled checked drive along the ground
Punch through mid-off with less elevation
Firm push back past the bowler
alt_aggressive: Aim over long-off when field is up
Hit over long-on to target straight boundary
Inside-out loft over extra cover
final_feedback: Build a strong base before swinging hard.
Do not lose your head position while going aerial.
Extend your arms fully through contact.
Choose the gap before you swing.
Practise timing first, then power.

Pull Shot.summary: Short ball played with a horizontal bat toward the leg side.
Pull Shot.fields: Square leg, deep midwicket, fine leg.
Pull Shot.masters: Ricky Ponting, Rohit Sharma, Viv Richards
Pull Shot.history: Developed as a strong answer to fast short-pitched bowling.
Pull Shot.improve: Watch bounce early and get into position quickly.
alt_safe: Roll wrists to keep the ball down in front of square
Control the pull toward deep square for one or two
Drop the ball to leg side for a quick single
alt_aggressive: Front-foot pull over midwicket for six
Back-foot pull into the stands at deep midwicket
Hook variation over fine leg rope
final_feedback: Judge the length early before committing.
Get into position quickly on either front or back foot.
Keep your eyes level while the ball rises.
Roll your wrists if you want to keep the ball down.
Practise on slower bowling before facing real pace.

Hook Shot.summary: Pull shot variation played to a head-high bouncer.
Hook Shot.fields: Fine leg and backward square leg.
Hook Shot.masters: Brian Lara, Ricky Ponting, Chris Gayle
Hook Shot.history: Used especially when bowlers target the helmet with bouncers.
Hook Shot.improve: Keep eyes level; roll wrists to keep ball down if playing safely.
alt_safe: Drop gloves and let the ball go if unsafe
Glance the ball fine for a controlled boundary
Roll wrists to keep the hook down to deep square
alt_aggressive: Full-blooded hook over fine leg
Hook into the crowd at deep square leg
Stand tall and pull in front of square for six
final_feedback: Never hook blindly; always see the ball clearly.
Maintain balance even while rotating your body.
Practise ducking and swaying as well as attacking.
Decide early if you will attack or evade.
Wear proper protection when practising the hook.

Sweep.summary: Front-foot rotation sweep against spin played along the ground.
Sweep.fields: Square leg, fine leg, backward square.
Sweep.masters: Joe Root, Yuvraj Singh, Matthew Hayden
Sweep.history: A dominant shot especially in subcontinent pitches versus spinners.
Sweep.improve: Strong front-knee base and balance while swinging.
alt_safe: Soft sweep into vacant square leg
Fine sweep along the ground to fine leg
Controlled sweep between fielders for ones and twos
alt_aggressive: Slog sweep over deep midwicket
Big sweep into the stands at backward square leg
Flat sweep over square leg boundary
final_feedback: Get low with a stable front knee.
Keep your head level to avoid losing sight of the ball.
Swing smoothly, not too fast, to control placement.
Practise both conventional and fine sweeps.
Read the length; avoid sweeping balls that are too full.

Slog Sweep.summary: A power sweep hit in the air over the leg-side field.
Slog Sweep.fields: Deep midwicket, cow corner, straight midwicket boundary.
Slog Sweep.masters: Yuvraj Singh, Glenn Maxwell, Rishabh Pant
Slog Sweep.history: A T20 power shot used to counter spinners aggressively.
Slog Sweep.improve: Stable lower body and keep eyes on the ball during fearless swing.
alt_safe: Roll the wrists to keep the slog sweep down to deep midwicket
Target the gap between deep square and long-on along the ground
Switch to a conventional sweep if field is spread
alt_aggressive: Big slog over cow corner for six
Flat slog sweep just over infield fielders
Aim at vacant stands between deep midwicket and long-on
final_feedback: Commit fully when you choose the slog sweep.
Bend your knees to stay balanced when swinging hard.
Keep watching the ball until the very last moment.
Practise hitting with shape, not just brute power.
Know the field—aim into big gaps, not at fielders.

Late Cut.summary: Shot played softly behind point using the ball's pace.
Late Cut.masters: Kane Williamson, Sachin Tendulkar, Steve Smith
Late Cut.history: Originated on fast English pitches to use ball pace to score behind point.
Late Cut.improve: Play it late and let the hands do the work.
alt_safe: Open the face to glide to third man along the ground
Drop the ball very fine to steal a single
Use late cut to beat the slip and gully cordon safely
alt_aggressive: Upper cut over slips for boundary
Hard late cut past backward point
Slash late over third man for six
final_feedback: Play the ball very late under your eyes.
Relax your hands to let the ball run off the bat face.
Keep a light grip to control touch and placement.
Practise against throwdowns aimed outside off stump.
Know when to leave the ball instead of cutting.

Square Cut.summary: Back-foot shot hit square of the wicket on the off side.
Square Cut.fields: Point, backward point, deep cover point.
Square Cut.masters: Virender Sehwag, Sanath Jayasuriya, Steve Smith
Square Cut.history: A dominating shot against width outside off stump.
Square Cut.improve: Get on top of the bounce to avoid hitting in the air.
alt_safe: Punch square along the ground in front of point
Open the face to guide behind point for a single
Check your swing to keep the ball down to sweeper cover
alt_aggressive: Slash hard over point
Hit square cut over backward point
Upper cut over third man on short and wide balls
final_feedback: Move your weight slightly onto the back foot before swinging.
Get on top of the bounce for a safe ground stroke.
Avoid throwing your hands too hard at the ball.
Practise controlling the cut shot with softer hands.
Pick balls that are short and wide—don’t cut everything.

Paddle Scoop.summary: Unorthodox shot scooped over the keeper or fine leg.
Paddle Scoop.fields: Fine leg, short fine leg, third man.
Paddle Scoop.masters: AB de Villiers, Tillakaratne Dilshan, Glenn Maxwell
Paddle Scoop.history: A modern T20 creation to attack fine-leg fielders.
Paddle Scoop.improve: Watch ball closely, get into low position, use bowler’s pace.
alt_safe: Soft paddle to fine leg for one
Deflect ball gently over short fine leg
Glide the ball to third man instead of scooping
alt_aggressive: Full ramp over keeper for six
Big scoop over fine leg rope
Reverse scoop over short third man
final_feedback: Practise this shot only after mastering basic strokes.
Get very low and balanced before scooping.
Keep your eyes level while the ball is delivered.
Use the bowler’s pace rather than swinging too hard.
Be aware of field setting and boundary length.

Reverse Sweep.summary: Switch stance and sweep the ball opposite-handed.
Reverse Sweep.fields: Backward point, third man, deep cover.
Reverse Sweep.masters: Kevin Pietersen, Glenn Maxwell, Jos Buttler
Reverse Sweep.history: A popular skill-shot in modern T20 cricket.
Reverse Sweep.improve: Quick hand switch and maintain balance while rotating.
alt_safe: Reverse tap behind point for one
Roll wrists to keep reverse sweep down
Use reverse paddle to fine third man region
alt_aggressive: Reverse slog sweep over point for six
Big reverse hit over deep cover
Flat reverse sweep between point and third man
final_feedback: Practise the hand change slowly at first.
Maintain a strong base while rotating your body.
Only play it to balls within your hitting arc.
Decide early whether to play normal or reverse sweep.
Use this shot when field is stacked on leg side.

Flick Shot.summary: Front-foot shot with wrist work to hit toward the leg side.
Flick Shot.masters: VVS Laxman, KL Rahul, Rohit Sharma
Flick Shot.history: Iconic on subcontinent pitches with strong wristy batters.
Flick Shot.improve: Roll wrists and use timing rather than raw strength.
alt_safe: Soft flick to square leg for one
Glance fine for easy runs
Controlled flick between midwicket and square leg
alt_aggressive: Whip over deep midwicket for six
Flick over fine leg rope
Pick up shot over backward square leg
final_feedback: Let the ball come to you before flicking.
Use your wrists to control direction and power.
Keep your head still even while rotating the bat.
Practise against straight balls on pads, not wide ones.
Avoid overcommitting across the crease.

Helicopter Shot.summary: A signature power yorker shot using heavy wrist rotation.
Helicopter Shot.history: Invented and made famous by MS Dhoni using incredible wrist power.
Helicopter Shot.improve: Strong bottom-hand wrist snap and lower body power.
alt_safe: Drive yorkers along the ground for safe singles
Turn straight balls into flicks if risk is high
Check your swing if timing is off
alt_aggressive: Full helicopter into cow corner
Helicopter shot straight over long-on
Running helicopter when charging bowler
final_feedback: Build forearm and wrist strength progressively.
Practise on slower bowling before full pace.
Time the ball at the very last moment of the swing.
Keep a low, stable base for big power.
Use this shot sparingly as a surprise weapon.

Upper Cut.summary: Late cut in the air using bounce of a short-pitched wide ball.
Upper Cut.fields: Third man and deep point boundary.
Upper Cut.masters: Sachin Tendulkar, Virender Sehwag, Suryakumar Yadav
Upper Cut.history: First seen regularly in ODI cricket against short-and-wide fast bowling.
Upper Cut.improve: Use bounce and keep soft hands for safe execution.
alt_safe: Guide the ball over slip cordon for a controlled boundary
Open the face to run the ball down to third man
Leave the ball if it is too wide or too high
alt_aggressive: Full upper cut over third man
Hard cut over deep point
Attack short and wide balls over the infield
final_feedback: Wait for the ball to rise before playing.
Play with soft hands to control the deflection.
Practise judging short and wide lengths.
Avoid throwing your bat too hard at the ball.
Use this shot mainly when there is no third man.
